Subject: Lunch with Steve Carter
Description:
Steve,

Thanks for your interest in my group and for introducing yourself. I'd be glad to get together and talk about the kinds of things we're up to. Please contact my assistant Lori Federico, and ask her to find an hour in my schedule -- perhaps over lunch -- some time in the next couple of weeks.

Paul 
-------------------------------------
Paul M. Goldbart, Professor and Chair 
School of Physics - Georgia Institute of Technology
837 State Street, Atlanta, GA 30332-0430, U.S.A.
Email: paul.goldbart@physics.gatech.edu 
Website: www.physics.gatech.edu/~pgoldbart6/
Phone: (404) 894-5200 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello Paul,

  My name is Steve Carter and I am one of the first year graduate students. I hope my message finds you well. I am writing to express a formal interest in your research, specifically your theoretical work in the quantum mechanics of fluids and solids. I don't know if you are planning to take on any new graduate students this year, but I would love to find out more about your research. Of course, if you do foresee having an availability of funds for taking on a graduate student for dissertation research I would be quite interested to discover that as well. If you are available this week or sometime soon I would love to arrange a time to meet with you and discuss it. Even if you do not plan to have funds for another graduate student next year, I would still really love to speak with you because I really want to conduct research in theoretical quantum mechanics and I am sure that you would be a great source of advice on how I can make this happen.

  A bit about me. I studied both physics and mathematics as an undergraduate at the small liberal arts school Birmingham-Southern College. I love mathematical formalism and make every attempt to be very detailed in my work and understand concepts at the most fundamental level I can. My research experience as an undergraduate consisted primarily of experimental nuclear physics (REU, Duke university) and theoretical work in pure mathematics (specifically, abstract algebra) and I feel that theoretical work is my passion and the path I would like to pursue in graduate school. I have provided my CV and resume should you chose to review them.


I look forward to hearing from you,

Best,
Steve Carter

Subject: Mathematics Seminar: Math is in the eye of the beholder by Andre Martinez-Finkelshtein (Universidad de Almeria)
Description:
Friday, November 14, 2014 --- 11:00am --- Skiles 005

Applied and Computational Mathematics Seminar: Math is in the eye of
the beholder
by Andre Martinez-Finkelshtein (Universidad de Almeria)

The medical imaging benefits from the advances in constructive
approximation, orthogonal polynomials, Fourier and numerical
analysis, statistics and other branches of mathematics. At the same time,
the needs of the medical diagnostic technology pose new mathematical
challenges. This talk surveys a few problems, some of them related
to approximation theory, that have appeared in my collaboration with
specialists studying some pathologies of the human eye, in particular,
of the cornea, such as:
- reconstruction of the shape of the cornea from the data collected by
  keratoscopes
- implementation of simple indices of corneal irregularity
- fast and reliable computation of the through-focus characteristics
  of a human eye.
Organizer: Martin Short

Subject: National Engineering Forum: G.P. Peterson, M. Cassidy
Description:
G.P. "Bud" Peterson
President
Georgia Institute of Technology

&

C. Michael Cassidy
President & CEO
Georgia Research Alliance

Cordially invite you to attend
 
THE NATIONAL ENGINEERING FORUM
to join an exclusive, invitation-only dialogue with leaders from industry, academia, government, and other sectors to discuss solutions – based on the distinctiveness of the Atlanta region – to the engineering crises of capacity, capability, and competitiveness. 
THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 2014
6 - 6:45 p.m. Cocktail Reception
6:45 - 8:30 p.m. Dinner, Keynote, and Roundtable Discussion

"TECH TOWER"
Lettie Pate Whitehead Evans Administration Building
Georgia Institute of Technology
225 North Avenue NW, Atlanta, GA
The evening will begin with cocktails and remarks from

Thomas A. Fanning
 Chairman, President & CEO 
Southern Company
Jeffery J. Wilcox
Vice President of Engineering
Lockheed Martin

Deborah L. Wince-Smith
President and CEO
Council on Competitiveness. 
Register Now
Please RSVP by November 6th. If you have questions, please contact Chad Evans, Executive Vice President, Council on Competitiveness at 202-969-3410. 
WHAT IS NEF? Throughout America’s history, engineers have provided a wellspring of innovation to drive our economic growth and national security. The U.S. engineering enterprise is facing a crisis of capacity, capability and competitiveness - the 3 C's.

CAPACITY: America needs quantity, quality and diversity in the engineering workforce, including homegrown talent to fill critical national security roles. Young people are not entering engineering fields in sufficient numbers to replace retiring engineers. 
 
CAPABILITY: America needs skilled engineers versed in multiple disciplines. Emerging, multidisciplinary engineering and technology fields need a workforce trained to solve challenges in sustainability, climate change and evolving areas such as cyber-security, advanced manufacturing, cloud architecture, energy and healthcare.
 
COMPETITIVENESS: The engineering enterprise is the underpinning of America’s productivity and prosperity. The engineering community must work more creatively and collaboratively – alongside political leaders and media – and make the case for the essential role engineering plays in fueling our economy, bolstering national security and advancing U.S. leadership.
 
The National Engineering Forum is a movement focused on creating solutions for the three challenges facing the U.S. engineering enterprise. In 2014, leaders from industry, academia, the national laboratories and other sectors will meet in engineering and innovation hubs such as the Atlanta region to celebrate this heritage, and launch a national conversation – the National Engineering Forum – on the future of America’s engineering enterprise and the role of engineers to position the nation for 21st century leadership. The dialogues will culminate in a national cornerstone event.

Subject: Stamatios Krimigis: CSTAR Distinguished Lecture: Voyager After 37 Years in Space
Description:
The Center for Space Technology and Research (CSTAR) cordially invites you to attend the premier event of the CSTAR Distinguished Seminar Series. We are honored to feature Dr. Stamatios Krimigis who will present, "The Voyager spacecraft after 37 years in space: The quest for traveling beyond our solar system" which will provide discussion of an array of fascinating highlights of over 30 years of scientific discoveries.
 Dr. Stamatios Krimigis is Principal Investigator on several NASA spacecraft, including Voyagers 1 and 2 to the Outer Planets and the Voyager Interstellar Mission, and the Cassini-Huygens mission to Saturn and Titan. He and colleagues proposed and implemented the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (NEAR) mission and oversaw its landing on the asteroid Eros on February 12, 2000, the first ever landing on an asteroid. He has designed and built instruments that have flown to all eight planets, and also the New Horizons mission currently headed to Pluto. 
Dr. Stamatios Krimigis received his B.S. Physics from the University of Minnesota (1961), his M.S. (1963) and Ph.D. (1965) in Physics from the University of Iowa, and served on the faculty there. In 1968 he moved to the Applied Physics Laboratory of Johns Hopkins University, became Chief Scientist in 1980, Space Department Head in 1991, and Emeritus Head in 2004. The Space Department has designed, built and operated more than 65 spacecraft, and expanded its activities to planetary missions during his tenure.
He has published more than 560 papers in peer-reviewed journals and books on the physics of the sun, interplanetary medium, planetary magnetospheres, and the heliosphere, with over 11,000 citations. He is recipient of NASA’s Exceptional Scientific Achievement Medal three times (1981, 1986, 2014), is a Fellow of the American Physical Society (APS), American Geophysical Union (AGU), American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), and American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA), recipient of COSPAR’s Space Science Award in 2002, a recipient of the Basic Sciences Award of the International Academy of Astronautics (1994) where he chairs the Board of Trustees for Basic Sciences, awardee of the Council of European Aerospace Societies CEAS Gold Medal for 2011, recipient of the Jean Dominique Cassini Medal of the European Geophysical Union, the AIAA James Van Allen Space Environments Medal, both for 2014, a member of the Academy of Athens since 2005 occupying the Chair of “Science of Space”, and chairman of Greece’s National Council of Research and Technology (2010-2013). He holds Honorary Doctorates from the Universities of the Aegean, Athens, and the International Hellenic University.
About the Center for Space Technology and Research (CSTAR):
The Center for Space Technology and Research (C-STAR) organizes, integrates, and facilitates Georgia Tech's space science and technology research activities. C-STAR brings together a wide range of Georgia Tech faculty who are active in space-related research and functions as a focal point for the growth of the space industry in the state of Georgia. C-STAR personnel are advancing the frontiers of astrophysics, Earth science, planetary science, robotics, space policy, space technology, and space systems engineering. C-STAR was established in 2013 and is led by Robert D. Braun (Director) and Thomas Orlando (Associate Director). C-STAR is actively engaged in partnerships with NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, the Georgia Department of Economic Development Center of Innovation for Aerospace, and the Georgia Space Grant Consortium.

Subject: OHR Transition Assessment - discuss current and future needs and the challenges and opportunities facing OHR. *notes*
Description:
Challenges... 

* We're not a corporation and you don't want us to be. Understand how higher ed in general (and specifically research intensive higher ed) really work. 

* The College is here to serve the schools: and they are there to to research and teach. That's our bottom line. It needs to be HR's, too. 

* Faculty hiring: There's no cookie-cutter model, they're all different and should he handled as such. Otherwise we'll simply fail to hire the best and we'll erode instead of improving. 

* Lateral moves have stringent constraints on compensation changes. This limits career advancement and drives away the people we want at GT. 

* IT and market forces: We need to be attentive and flexible. 

* Bottom line: HR is only there to enable GT to get done what it should, not to stand in the the way. Be partners not adversaries.

Subject: NSF NRT Proposal....Season Opens (and, yes, another Doodle poll)

Hello, you have received this because of your participation in last year’s rush-job NSF-NRT proposal, or because you have expressed interest.

The distribution list does not yet include our off-campus participants. Additional people may be added…a group decision.

NRT is the successor to IGERT. This year, we have the opportunity to do better. Our educational plan has been refined, but we still need a better scientific focus. To find a time that works for regular planning meetings, I have established a Doodle poll.

http://doodle.com/f6rq3yxa8z656rxp

IT IS NOT THE USUAL “AVAILABLE TIMES” POLL, BUT THE NEGATIVE OF THAT. PLEASE MARK DOWN YOUR REGULAR WEEKLY SCHEDULE: TEACHING, GROUP MEETING, SEMINARS, WHATEVER. THE WEEK INDICATED IN THE POLL IS ARBITRARY. ALSO, THE FRIDAY 10 PM TIME SLOT IS ACCIDENTAL…IGNORE THAT!

Below is the last email about NRT from last year, complete with the internal reviews. I take them as mostly positive, and the problems are fixable. NSF lists NRT as “anticipated” but last year’s RFP has not been updated. It does not matter: surely there will be some competition for the IGERT successor.

Paul

******************************************************************

We were not selected for NRT. It’s easy to understand: thanks to spotty delivery of the memo about an internal deadline, and not being aggressive enough to find out sooner, we wrote this in < 24 hours and barely made an EXTENDED deadline. Not enough time to put down the ideas we had in our concept meetings. If we had been selected, other teams could have complained! So this could have been DOA and OSP was just smart enough to let us get some feedback.

Good news: The reviews express enthusiasm for the general idea. In some cases—inclusion of people from other departments—we probably all agree with the reviewers. In other cases, we will want to sharpen our arguments. With regular meetings and attention to the positive suggestions we will be in good shape to try again.

I was pleased to see the importance the reviewers placed on working with other universities. Subject: Fink Lecture: Paul Weiss
Description:
2014 Fink Lecture
Thursday, February 19, 2015, 4:00 – 5:00 pm, MoSE G011
 
Prof. Paul Weiss
Professor, Department of Chemistry, Department of Materials Science and Engineering
Editor-in-Chief, ACS Nano
 
web site: http://www.nano.ucla.edu
 
Cooperative Function in Atomically Precise Nanoscale Assemblies
 
Abstract
We use molecular design, tailored syntheses, intermolecular interactions, and selective chemistry to direct molecules into desired positions to create nanostructures, to connect functional molecules to the outside world, and to serve as test structures for measuring single or bundled molecules. Interactions within and between molecules can be designed, directed, measured, understood, and exploited at unprecedented scales. Such interactions can be used to form precise molecular assemblies, nanostructures, and patterns, and to control and to stabilize function. We selectively test hypothesized mechanisms by varying molecular design, chemical environment, and measurement conditions to enable or to disable function and control using predictive and testable means. Critical to understanding these variations has been developing the means to make tens to hundreds of thousands of independent single-molecule/assembly measurements in order to develop sufficiently significant statistical distributions, while retaining the heterogeneity inherent in the measurements. We measure the electronic coupling of the molecules and substrates by measuring the polarizabilities of the connected functional molecules. The next step in such devices is to learn to assemble and to operate molecules together, both cooperatively and hierarchically, in analogy to biological muscles. We discuss our initial efforts in this area, in which we find both interferences and cooperativity.

Dear Dean Goldbart:

 

On behalf of the entire volunteer membership of the Steering Committee for CAMPAIGN GEORGIA TECH, we are delighted to congratulate you and your academic and development teams on reaching your goal of eighty million dollars a full year ahead of schedule. The College of Sciences becomes the second college to cross the finish line.

 

Even with the recent commitments tied to EBB, and estate gift provisions from multiple donors, including those in honor of Charlie Liotta and to advance public science outreach, we are sure that the College has funding opportunities still unmet in the current campaign period and for which the College will be focused in the remaining months of CAMPAIGN GEORGIA TECH – most likely in the form of an endowed Dean’s Chair, an expanded number of endowed school chairs, faculty chairs and professorships, undergraduate scholarships and graduate fellowships, and perhaps dean’s discretionary endowment funds. With best personal regards, and our congratulations to the entire College of Sciences community.

 

John F Brock III

Mary Rockett Brock

Co-Chairs, CAMPAIGN GEORGIA TECH

Subject: Make remarks at the Grad Leadership Program graduation (Temenoff/Blum)
Description:
http://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Saul_Bellow
"There is simply too much to think about. It is hopeless — too many kinds of special preparation are required. In electronics, in economics, in social analysis, in history, in psychology, in international politics, most of us are, given the oceanic proliferating complexity of things, paralyzed by the very suggestion that we assume responsibility for so much. This is what makes packaged opinion so attractive."
  Saul Bellow 
  "There Is Simply Too Much to Think About" (1992), pp. 173-174


Paul, 

I am in charge of organizing the graduate leadership program (GLP) this year. Several of the students from last year remarked that they very much enjoyed your insights during their “graduation” evening and we would love it if you could join us again. This year’s “graduation” is 5:30-7:30 pm on 5/4/15 and will be the same format as last year – a few minutes for remarks about your leadership journey followed by Q&A with the students. 

I hope you will be able to join us – thanks very much for considering it! 

Best wishes for 2015, 

Johnna Temenoff
